summary: MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is an enveloped, positive-sense single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus classified as belonging to the Betacoronavirus genus of the Coronaviridae family. more than 1,700 cases spanning 27 different countries, with an overall case fatality rate of just over 35%. only one PLP is encoded, papain-like protease (PLpro) the PLpro and 3C-like protease are responsible for cleaving Nsp1 to Nsp3 and Nsp4 to Nsp16. intriguingly, coV PLpros have additional roles beyond simply cleaving Nsp1 to Nsp3 to promote viral replication (11) direct disruption of PLpro's deubiquitinase and deISGylase proteolytic activities together was shown to remove antagonism of the IFN-I response in part due to suppression of Ub-dependent mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS)-mediated signaling. a lack of structural information pertaining to how MERS-CoV PLpro accommodates ISG15s limited their ability to delineate whether the MERS-CoV PLpro's deubiquitinase, deISGylase, or both activities were critical for effective IFN-I antagonism by MERS-CoV or other CoV PLPs (17). however, no structures illuminating the interface of MERS-CoV and ISG15s have similarly Phe149 of the ChISG15 is lost in the MERS-CoV complex due to the replacement with a valine, which is not close enough to make an interaction. a minor improvement of MERS-CoV PLpro for northern shrew ISG15 was observed. a faint cleavage product was observed at the 30-min mark. however, this improvement was very minor, suggesting additional differences between northern shrew and human ISG15s may also play a factor in the species specificity of MERS-CoV PLpro. the peptide represents the consensus sequence for both Ub and ISG15. it is used as a control to ensure that intrinsic catalytic activity is not significantly impacted. the mutations failed to reduce deISGylase activity, implying that residues in the Ubl could play a role in some interactions. 11 mutations were designed for their potential to selectively disrupt the interface between MERS-CoV PLpro and hISG15 without appreciably impacting deubiquitinase and peptidase activities. mutants shown in green have reduced activity toward ISG15-AMC, the mutant shown in magenta showed little change in activity. four of these mutations, V225D, V225A, Q227A, and R232V, had no significant impact on any activity. however, one mutation, V225P, unexpectedly increased activity toward both Ub-AMC and ISG15-AMC. PLpro's Arg234 and hISG15's Glu127 boosted protease activity toward Ub-AMC. the removal of the charged residue leaves a predominantly hydrophobic surface. the most successful mutations to remove deISGylase activity occurred at positions 176 and 210. the effect of the V210D mutation is a reduction of deISGylase activity to 4%. the effect of the mutation is a reduction of deISGylase activity to 4%. however, no complete cleavage of pro-hISG15 is observed for K176E after 60 min. the mutants possessed a Km of 3.17 0.366 M and kcat of 12.22 0.430 M1 min1 for Ub. the mutant V210D had a 3-fold elevated Km of 10.04 2.33, echoing the weaker binding of Ub observed on the ITC. however, it also possessed a 3-fold higher kcat of 29.44 2.40 M1 min1. V210D's kcat/Km of 0.23 0.050 M1 min1 and K176E's kcat/Km of 0.74 0.170 M1 min1 were more reflective of the kcat/Km of 0.3 0.1 reported for the hISG15 substrate. a similar kcat/Km of 0.33 0.066 M1 min1 was observed for a crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever viral ovarian tumor domain ( ITC data, as well as other mutational data, supported the idea that this interaction extends to the N-terminal domain of ISG15 for SARS-CoV PLpro (19, 20). Specifically, the C-terminal domain of hISG15 (ChISG15) was found to have weaker affinity and a different thermodynamic profile than full-length hISG15. a simpler explanation may be that the N-terminal domain of hISG15 does not play as significant a role for MERS-CoV PLpro as it does for SAR-CoV PLpro. this explanation would also imply that the C-terminal domain of hISG15 plays the dominant role in forming favorable interactions with MERS CoV PLpro. the protease's Ub-like fold of ChISG15 was found in close proximity to the fingers and palm domains of MERS-CoV PLpro. the ub-like fold of ChISG15 was found in close proximity to the fingers and palm domains of MERS-CoV PLpro. the PLpro is shown in gold, and ChISG15 is shown in teal. the structural domains of MERS-CoV PLpro consist of the fingers (white), palm (lavender), thumb (green) and Ubl (pink) Domains. ase is made up of interactions between his171 and Arg168 of the MERS-CoV PLpro and ChISG15 residues Pro130 and Trp123. the other is comprised of the insertion of ChISG15's Lys129 side chain into a pocket generated by the carbonyl groups of the PLpro's Lys205 and Cys208. this differs from the open state of the protease (PDB 4RF1) where the Zn fingers are found peeled away from Ub, limiting the protease's interaction with the substrate. the zinc atom is shown as a black sphere. lone exception is Arg155, whose long flexible side chain forms hydrostatic interactions with the carbonyl of Val276 of the protease instead of Pro163. this change appears to have minimal impact on the backbone, suggesting that the differences in orientation of ISG15 versus Ub within the UIM are likely the primary driver of the backbone deviations. the latter open state of MERS-CoV PLpro-Ub is more representative of the recently elucidated SARS-CoV PLpro-ChISG15 structure. this could indicate that, much like PLpro's interaction with Ub, more than one bound state of hISG15 in a PLpro may also exist. for the SARS-CoV PLpro, this may offer an explanation of how the remaining distance found in current models would require movement of the bound Ch two of the hydrophobic interactions that drive the MERS-CoV PLpro's interaction with the ChISG15 are absent from the SARS-CoV PLpro and ChISG15 complex due to the more closed conformation of the zinc finger of the MERS-CoV PLpro. this conformation allows for one of the loops that coordinate the zinc to come in closer proximity to the ChISG15, creating a large hydrophobic seam. the lack of efficacy toward northern tree shrew ISG15 may originate from differences between northern tree shrew ISG15 and hISG15 at positions 144 and 145. a minor improvement of MERS-CoV PLpro for northern shrew ISG15 was observed. a faint cleavage product was observed at the 30-min mark, in line with greater cleavage at the 60-min mark. the activity of wild-type MERS-CoV PLpro as well as MERS-CoV PLpro containing disruptive mutations at those sites was assessed using three substrates. these were Ub-AMC, ISG15-AMC, and the small peptide Z-RLRGG-AMC, which are designed utilizing the 7-amino-4-methylcoumarin (AMC) leaving group. mutants with attenuated deISGylase activity were sought. 11 mutations were designed for their potential to selectively disrupt the interface between MERS-CoV PLpro and hISG15 without appreciably impacting deubiquitinase and peptidase activities. close-up interactions of mutants that specifically reduce activity toward ISG15-AMC. four of these mutations, V225D, V225A, Q227A, and R232V, had no substantial impact on any activity. however, one mutation unexpectedly increased activity toward both Ub-AMC and ISG15-AMC. mutation was initially designed to disrupt salt bridge interactions between PLpro's Arg234 and hISG15's Glu127. this alteration inadvertently boosted protease activity toward Ub-AMC. the removal of the charged residue leaves a predominantly hydrophobic surface. the introduction of aspartic acid was designed to take advantage of the differences at Ub's Arg42, Ile44, and Gln49 and hISG15's Trp123, Thr125, and Pro130 residues. there was a concern that this might also disrupt the nearby hydrophobic path involving Ub's Ile44. however, the deubiquitinase activity remains near wild-type levels, suggesting either that this does not occur or that perhaps any disruption the mutant exhibited weaker binding to Ub, with a KD of 200.50 7.77 M, that could be the source of the 20% reduction of deubiquitinase activity observed for V210D. the mutant had a 3-fold elevated Km of 10.04 2.33, echoing the weaker binding of Ub observed on the ITC. Error was calculated using the standard deviation. the lysate was subjected to centrifugation at 70,600 g for 30 min. the soluble fraction was collected and filtered through a 0.8-m-pore-size filter. the eluted protein was furthered purified using a superdex 200 column. all injections were kept at a constant temperature of 25°C. both the protease and substrate were dialyzed into 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.3), 200 mM NaCl, 1 mM DTT, and 0.1 mM ZnCl2 overnight at 4°C. the complex was dialyzed in 250 mM NaCl, 25 mM HEPES (pH 7.0), 2 mM DTT, and 0.1 mM ZnCl2 overnight with thrombin to cleave a 6His tag. the thrombin-cleaved complex was further purified by size exclusion chromatography using a superdex 75 column (GE Healthcare, Pittsburgh, PA) preequilibrated with 100 m native and zinc single anomalous dispersion (Zn-SAD) data sets were collected at wavelengths of 1.0 and 1.2837, respectively, using the 22-ID beamline at Argonne National Labs. a hybrid substructure search was used to find Zn sites. each protease was tested against commercially available fluorogenic substrates of Ub, ISG15, and a peptide representing the shared C-terminal consensus sequence, Z-RLRGG. all assays were performed in duplicate at 25°C in 100 mM NaCl, 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 0.01 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, and 5 mM DTT in a 50-l reaction volume using 96-well reactions were run in 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM HEPES (pH 7.5) and 2 mM DTT at 37°C with 20 nM protease and 10 M proISG15. the reaction was quenched by mixing equal parts with 2 SDS-tricine sample buffer and boiling at 98°C for 5 min. the recombinant protein was lysed in 500 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris (pH 7.0) and 10 mM -mercaptoethanol (BME) for 30 min at 4°C. the cells were subsequently sonicated on ice at 50% power. the soluble fraction was collected and filtered through a 0.8-m-pore-size filter. ITC measurements of MERS-CoV PLpros with ChISG15 or Ub were performed using a previously described protocol (23). both the protease and substrate were dialyzed into 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.3), 200 mM NaCl, 1 mM DTT, and 0.1 mM ZnCl2 overnight at 4°C. the mixture was dialyzed in 250 mM NaCl, 25 mM HEPES (pH 7.0), 2 mM DTT, and 0.1 mM ZnCl2 overnight with thrombin to cleave a 6His tag. the thrombin-cleaved complex was further purified by size exclusion chromatography using a superdex 75 column (GE Healthcare, Pittsburgh, PA) final optimized condition consisted of 200 mM CaCl2, 100 mM NaO2C2H3 (pH 4.6) and 28% (vol/vol) MPD. crystals of MERS-CoV PLpro-ChISG15 were soaked in mother liquor. the resultant plasmids were transformed into Escherichia coli NEB-5 cells by heat shock. Mutant plasmids were confirmed by sequencing and transformed into BL21(DE3) cells. assays were run with 5 nM protease in a 30-l reaction volume. concentrations of Ub- and ISG15-AMC varying from 0.25 M to 20 M. reactions were initiated by the addition of protease. the reaction was quenched by mixing equal parts with 2 SDS-tricine sample buffer and boiling at 98°C for 5 min. samples were subsequently analyzed by SDS-PAGE on 10 to 20% mini-protean tris-tricine precast gels.
